A CAVE-like environment as a tool for full-size train design

A CAVE-like environment as a tool for full-size train design

  • Francisco J. Seron1,
  • Diego Gutierrez1,
  • Juan A. Magallon1,
  • Emilio J. Sobreviela1 &
  • Jose A. Gutierrez1 

Virtual Reality volume 7, pages82–93(2004)Cite this article

  • 170 Accesses

  • 10 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Simulations of models, in all different areas, is an expanding, attractive line of work. More and more applications are taking advantage of the improvements in technology and knowledge in this field, thus achieving results that would have been impossible to achieve with a real model, or foreseeing facts that otherwise would have been encountered too late in the production process. The rail industry is one possible beneficiary of this approach. Usually, before commencing the fabrication process of a new train, the construction of a full-size model is mandatory. Instead of building this full-size real model, which leaves little room for later, last-minute modifications, a virtual model can be built in the digital realm, thus offering a new platform for easier interaction with it. In this article, a simulation of a train is presented in order to tackle visual, aesthetic and ergonomic issues. The simulation runs on a PC-based CAVE-like architecture, offering a certain degree of interaction to the user, and combines static and dynamic computer-generated imagery, both with and without stereoscopy for 3D visualisation, as well as augmented virtuality techniques for the integration of the train with its environment.

Introduction

Simulation is a procedure that allows us to study a physical system by substituting it for another one which is more suitable for observation or measuring.

Different interests can be addressed by means of simulation. An astronaut can learn to pilot a space shuttle, a government can predict the evolution of the population in its country, a meteorologist can predict storms or a car company can preview its brand new model before it is actually built. These different approaches require different layers of complexity in the simulation: the astronaut trainer, for instance, will most likely need to be able to simulate the dynamics of the system to a certain degree. On the other hand, the car company might not need such realism if only the visual appearance is to be discussed by means of the simulation. But once the general shape is approved, it might then need to undergo a simulated wind tunnel test, which will require a new layer of complexity in the simulation. Thus, motivation guides the simulation itself.

Several simulations will work better by using virtual reality techniques [1, 2, 3]. These techniques create immersive environments that make the interaction between man and simulator as indistinguishable from reality as possible. Most of the time this implies the concept of real time, although, as we have seen, its necessity will be driven by the goal of the simulation. Fields where simulators are used more often include industry, civilian, military and entertainment [4], whilst several Internet addresses that offer information on some of the best simulators can be found at [5, 6].

Amongst all the different approaches to create an immersive environment, the CAVE system is one of the most popular [7, 8]. A great amount of literature exists on the subject, including [9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. It is important to mention that the terms “CAVE” or “cave” cannot be used to refer to generic technology, since the University of Illinois Board of Trustees registered the trademark, and subsequently licensed it to Fakespace Systems exclusively. Given this legal situation, we will refer to our system as “a CAVE-like system”, or CLS, understanding the system as a design tool made up of not only the hardware, but the control, design and presentation software that we describe here as well.

Different applications greatly differ in requirements for data accuracy and visualisation quality. Even when using state-of-the-art hardware and algorithms, it is not possible for a virtual reality system to support all the different visualisation demands at the same time. A user might just want to see detailed shape information for a given object, with accurate illumination or final material appearance being secondary. In that case, the information can most likely be presented based on real-time graphics. Other times the latter might be precisely what the user needs, and rendering accurate illumination or realistic materials is a task for which real time is not prepared, at least not yet. This balance between real-time and render quality is one of the main issues when designing a virtual reality system. In our case, the virtual reality system must help railway engineers to deal with different problems: the evaluation of the exterior design, the evaluation of the interior design, adequate lighting inside the train, ergonomics, etc. In each case, the most important aspect is the photorealistic quality of the imagery presented in the CLS system, making use of stereoscopy to accentuate the immersion [18, 19, 20, 21, 22]. This in turn rules out the notion of real-time graphics.

One of the fields that can largely benefit from the combination of simulation and virtual reality is what is known as virtual prototyping. Decisions made during the design phase of large scale engineering projects are often the most delicate ones, because of their possible dramatic effect on the final results, timing and costs. Mock-ups are routinely used for applications such as testing equipment integration, accessibility and space requirements in domains ranging from aerospace and automotive manufacturing to architecture [23, 24]. Virtual prototyping allows designers to test and improve their designs as if using physical mock-ups, but at an earlier stage, in a more versatile way and with greater opportunities for multi-site collaboration.

Natural interaction with digital models is very important, especially for testing purposes. In an attempt to overcome CAD systems’ interactivity and concurrent design limitations, large engineering projects have often been accompanied by the development of various kinds of specialised virtual prototyping tools [25]. Examples include the ISS VR Demonstrator used by Rolls-Royce to make an assessment of how easy it would be to build an engine and maintain it [26] and Boeing’s high-performance engineering visualisation system used during the design of the 777 [27]. Moreover, the French Space Agency (CNES) and CISI have jointly launched the PROVIS [28] research project in 1995 for developing solutions for satellite designers to create, manipulate and study their models using digital mock-ups, while CRS4 and CERN have jointly developed the i3d system for supporting the design of CERN’s Large Hadron Collider [29, 30]. These efforts show the interest of interactive virtual prototyping for early testing of designs.

Recently, research and development efforts for building virtual prototyping systems have been initiated independently from the needs of a specific project. Ongoing research at the Fraunhofer Center for Research in Computer Graphics involves studying how to integrate existing tools to provide virtual prototyping capabilities for existing CAD systems [31]. Some recent CAD add-on products such as PTC Pro/Fly-Through, Mechanical Dynamics ADAMS, Matra Datavision’s Megavision, Prosolvia Clarus Real-Time Link and the EDS Unigraphics Modelling module follow the same direction, providing real-time visualisation capabilities for engineering designs. Systems such as Division’s dV/Mock-up and dV/Reality, only available for PCs and SGI, have started to add limited interaction capabilities to high-performance rendering and, more importantly, a certain degree of support for concurrent model design. Working Model 3D, a windows/NT product by the American company Knowledge Revolution, which concentrates more on motion simulation than on real-time interaction, has been selected by readers of NASA Tech Brief as the most significant new product introduced to the engineering community in 1996. The ongoing ESPRIT project CAVALCALDE aims to advance the current state of the art by supporting and enhancing concurrent engineering practices, thanks to a distributed architecture enabling teams based in geographically dispersed locations to collaboratively design, test, validate and document a shared model.

Definition of the problem

Train manufacturing companies usually face two problems with regards to the design: reaching an agreement with the contractor on the final design of the unit (which involves the intelligent combining of both aesthetic and engineering aspects) and showing their design to other companies, people or the media in general. We will discuss these two topics in the following paragraphs.

The process of building a train is by no means simple. Usually, the contractor makes a call for tenders and, based on engineering aspects, awards the project to one of the proposers. Once the project is signed, the phase of designing the train begins. This might include a third party, concentrating only on this task. The process involves a lot of work, including conceptual designs, colour palettes, sketches, etc. The information goes back and forth between the parties involved, until the contractor is satisfied with the results.

This design process is very important; in fact, engineering considerations aside, the visual aspect plays a key role. How the public will accept the train depends of course on functionality issues such as speed or accessibility, but also on considerations relating comfort (are the seats too packed together? are the corridors wide enough? is the lighting correct?), ergonomics (is the monitor visible from this specific place? is the luggage area accessible?) and pure aesthetics (does this colour scheme work? do the shapes seem to belong to one unified design?). Currently, this design process is dealt with by building real full-size mock-ups, in which all these aspects can be studied.

To address most of these not-so-technical issues, the contract includes the construction of a full-size model of only one of the cars that make up the train (usually the most representative, due to budget limitations) as a requirement. More often than not, the contractor finds out that what worked as a sketch on paper does not work when built full-size in 3D, but changing it is costly in terms of time and money. Even though this full-size model approach allows a person to actually get into the car, walk through it, sit down to test the seats, etc., it imposes serious restrictions:

  • Size and mobility. The full-size model is obviously hard to transport from one place to another, thus limiting the physical space where it can be shown. Only one car is built, and it is a fixed model with no movement capabilities at all.

  • Versatility. After examining the full-size model, changes in shapes, lighting or appearance can only be performed by rebuilding whatever parts are involved in the changes, then reinstalling them. This is not only expensive, but involves heavy time delays as well. Consider the trouble it takes to change a critical element such as a seat, for instance, or a change in the colour of the floor which would involve installing a new carpet in the whole car.

  • Economy. These full-size models tend to be very expensive, which affects the number of changes that can be made within a reasonable budget.

  • Life. Once used and approved, the full-size model is usually destroyed for storage reasons.

After the real size model is built and the design has been agreed on, the company usually wants to show this design to the media or other partners. With the traditional way of building a real train car, the only way to do this is taking people to the physical location of the model. This again implies many of the same aforementioned restrictions.

As an alternative to this classical approach, the authors proposed the construction of a CAVE-like System (CLS). The CLS has been designed to overcome all these shortcomings and change the methodology of the design process, turning it into a cheaper and more flexible one. Specifically, by building a digital model, the abovementioned restrictions are done away with, while the following extra features are added:

  • Mobility. The proposed CLS can be dismantled and shipped for exhibition in different places or cities or in different scenarios (fairs, congresses, train stations, etc.) which helps the dissemination of the product. Also, scaled-down versions can be given away in CD or DVD formats for deeper and wider dissemination.

  • Versatility. All kinds of changes in shapes, lighting or appearance are feasible with the digital model, and much less costly in terms of time and money. Pre-planned changes and different options are only a mouse click away. For instance, the user can compare five different colour schemes, three types of seats and six floors to see which combination works best, add people, change from natural daylight to artificial night lighting, etc. On top of that, the digital model can simulate movement through rendered animations.

  • Economy. Once the initial hardware investment has been made, the digital approach is one order of magnitude cheaper than building the physical model. The first model, including the hardware investment reusable for subsequent models, has roughly the same cost as one full-size model.

  • Life. Digital information lasts virtually forever.

  • Extension. Using augmented virtuality techniques [32], the model can be inserted in real environments, or ergonomics can be studied by placing people and objects in the desired places, providing a greater sense of realism to the viewer at the same time.

  • Quality. The digital model is a good medium for presentations. In addition to this, the spectacular nature and innovative side of this approach is remarkable, which represents an added value for commercial and publicity issues.

  • Dissemination ease. Almost the same information that is displayed in the CLS (or a slightly modified or adapted version) can be stored in digital media like CD or DVD and widely distributed.

Considering all the pros and cons of the digital, virtual model approach, it makes sense to think it is worth the effort. The decision to build the digital model was made by Construcciones y Auxiliar de Ferrocarriles (CAF), Renfe Cercanías [33] and the Grupo de Informática Gráfica Avanzada (GIGA; Advanced Computer Graphics Group) of the University of Zaragoza. The proposed methodology changes the old full-size model paradigm, providing the CLS as a working system from the early stages of the design. The parties involved can propose a design, see it in a full-size stereoscopic display, change it or tweak it if necessary, go back to the CLS to test it and so on, until the cycle converges into the final design. Needless to say, all the changes done in the digital realm are a lot cheaper and can be done faster than with the real model. In addition to this, the digital model can be seen under different daylight conditions, at night, inside a tunnel, integrated with different real environments, with real people, etc. Computer generated imagery has therefore been generated, both static and animated, for regular and stereoscopic viewing. Our CAVE-like system is designed, in addition, as a medium to present the finished designs. These presentations might be aimed at a broad range of audiences, from the press to potential new contractors. With this in mind, the authors also generated the PreCAVE software, which allows any non-computer science expert to prepare presentations in a simple, fast way, choosing amongst all the different elements and formats that can be used, such as static imagery, videos stereoscopy or audio.

The following paragraphs describe the system specification as well as certain decisions taken during the implementation.

The system specification

A low-cost CLS has been chosen as the output format [34]. Four to six people can fit in comfortably, although there is only one ideal point of view from which perspective and stereoscopy appear to be perfect, since it is the point of view for which both have been calculated [35].

Given the nature of the project, the notion of real time has been turned down in favour of high quality imagery. That means that the images have all been prerendered, instead of using some graphic library such as OpenGL [36, 37] to calculate and display them in real time. A commercial modelling and animation package was used to produce the geometry, shaders and camera paths. The chosen rendering algorithm is based on ray tracing, using the in-house ALEPH software [38]. Ray tracing was favoured over more advanced global illumination methods such as photon mapping [39] due to the lesser time needed to generate one frame with the former approach. Global illumination effects such as soft shadows or colour bleeds are altered for a softer, more natural look than off-the-shelf straight ray tracing usually offers, by using simplifications such as shadow maps, the use of selective lights, or replacing real area lights with simpler, equivalent models. This also helps keep rendering times within reasonable limits.

The system is also able to play a continuous, predefined sequence of video and dynamic presentations of static imagery, so it can be used in an unattended way, suitable for presentations to the masses.

Hardware

Hardware-wise, the system is made up of the following elements:

  • Three flat panel screens for rear projection (two screens measuring 4 × 3 m, one measuring 3 × 3 m) assembled with a wedge frame, t-bars and light baffles. Additional characteristics are gained through 180 degrees of viewing angles. The washable, flame retardant screens do not depolarise the light projected on them to allow for stereoscopic images.

  • Six LCD projectors (XGA panel, 1800 ANSI lumen, 1024 × 768 native panel resolution) to project images and videos onto the screens.

  • Six fixed short focus lenses with a throw ratio of 0.9:1. They are used to reduce the distance between the projector and the screen, instead of folding the projectors’ optics using heavy and fragile mirrors.

  • Polarising filters placed in front of the projector lenses and polarizing glasses for the audience for stereoscopic views.

  • Two mid-sized PCs (P-III @ 800 Mhz, 256 MB RAM) running W2000. One is equipped with two MPEG-2 decoder cards, each one offering four channels of simultaneous MPEG-2 decoding. The two cards combined assure that the six videos projected during certain moments of the presentation (two for each eye times three screens) run in sync, preserving both the stereoscopic effect and the continuity between them. The other one will send static SVGA imagery, so it must have six SVGA output channels (different combinations of regular SVGA cards assure that).

The screens are supported by a frame made up of four beams assembled together, forming a rigid rectangle; the cantilevering wedge screen framing system allows each image to be rear projected completely to the outer edge of the seam—which minimises the apparent gap between all adjacent images. The screens material is flexible, thus allowing for easy transportation by just rolling them up carefully. To assemble them, the screens are unrolled over the frame, fastened to it and tightened with a towrope. Once the screens are completely assembled, their frames are fixed to one another in their final position, so that no additional structure is needed for the screens to stand in the upright position.

Viewer-centred perspective

Our aim is to have the users see exactly the same things at a scale of 1:1 that they would see if they were standing inside the real train. We had to make the projection planes in our perspective match the real CLS walls, with the projection focus exactly at the viewers’ position. Since our CLS renders offline in order to achieve the required photorealism in the images using low-end hardware, we had to choose an “ideal user” fixed viewer position inside it. The obvious choice is to have this ideal user standing at the centre of the floor, and looking at a point located at the centre of the front screen, at the same height as the viewer’s eyes (which are also fixed to a mean standard value of 1.65 m).

The viewer’s orientation is important for correct stereo projection, so we had to use the same orientation for all screens. Otherwise, we will end up with:

  • Inconsistencies at the edges of the CLS walls, since at least one eye has moved from one projection to another.

  • Incorrect views for two of the CLS walls for a given viewer orientation.

This means our CLS ideal user has to be looking at the front wall, while the side walls are used to fill the field of view, i.e., to be seen through the corner of the eye; if the user rotates his head to look directly to, say, the left wall, he will not see a real stereo view. Figure 1 shows this viewer-centred perspective.

This off-axis projection must be achieved by using the standard perspective available in most rendering software, which allows just a symmetric projection around the viewing axis (the usual “camera view”). An easy way to get the desired asymmetric projection (remember we have to render both eyes’ views, so they will be displaced a bit from the ideal user’s centre) is to render at the minimum resolution which will cover the full projection plane, then crop to the final wall coordinates. Figure 2 represents this for a left eye projection.

As we can see in Fig. 2, the symmetric standard perspective which covers the desired projection plane, centred at the viewer’s position, is obtained by increasing the resolution in a quantity equal to two times the distance between the viewer’s eye and the perpendicular axis to the centre of the plane(s). This operation should be done both for width (when the viewer is not exactly at the centre of the CLS, or for stereo views when the viewer is located at the centre, where we have to use the eye-separation value, estimated as 57 mm) and height (in order to take into account the fact that the viewer’s eyes are locate above the centre of the wall).

From this theoretical resolution, measured in “real” units, we will have to crop off the region which lies outside the wall, which obviously will match the increment used (2 s) and will be located at the closest edge to the viewer. Then both the final resolution and the crop window have to be translated to pixel units using the projection device resolution (720 × 576 for MPEG-2 PAL output and 1024 × 768 for SVGA).

This process needs to be performed six times (three screens times two eyes). We used a simple program, designed as a plug-in for the rendering software, which would take the input data shown in Fig. 3 and would define the six cameras necessary for correct stereoscopy.

The video display and the slide show

We face two main issues in the process of designing the video display subsystem:

  • The ability to deliver six (three stereo pairs) video streams in real time from a single computer.

  • The need to synchronise their playing at frame level.

The first point above led us to require special hardware to accomplish the goals. The solution adopted consists of using some specific add-on cards to play the six MPEG2 streams synchronised. Each of these cards offers 4 MPEG2 hardware decoders, and are able to read input data directly from a UltraSCSI disk, bypassing the PCI bus and accessing the storage device directly. With a modern drive with performance capabilities near the 30-40 MB/s range for data throughput, we are able to feed each decoder with a stream rated at about 5-10 Mbits/s, reaching and surpassing the quality of commercial DVD movies. The cards are managed by a custom written program, based on the available SDK. This SDK offers a very low-level API for programming the cards, giving some basic functionality as initialising the cards, setting input device configuration (PCI bus, direct SCSI), querying their state (play, pause, error...), launching stream playback and some simple synchronisation functionality (sync on frame or time basis). We had to implement the high-level flow logic of the system, the error recovery and reliability control (to detect frame drops or stream errors and restart streams on desired points), and a friendly user interface on top of that. GUI programming was done with the GTK+2.0 for Windows library, that offers both an efficient and complete toolkit.

The dynamic slide show program has a very clear purpose: it takes six images and displays them on six monitors. The main problems come from the state of the technology in commodity-off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware in PCs.

Because of hardware restrictions, only six slides plus the transition to the next set can be stored in memory, so the rest of the slides that made up the presentation must be loaded in real time. For this purpose we designed a prefetching and cacheing system that loads from disk the next frame the user is going to see after displaying the current one. This renders the computer unusable while heavily reading from disk (and perhaps decompressing JPEG or other format), but this time is spent by the users either discussing what is on screen at that moment or just paying attention to the specific details shown in the picture. We also wanted the presentation to include some nice effects, such as fading between slides. This effect is barely used when the CLS system is used during the design phase (people working and discussing the details want to jump quickly between slides), but offers a very interesting enhancement when the system is used for shows or presentations, since in this type of situation a smooth fade is usually more pleasant to the eye than a straight cut.

Hardware acceleration for graphics is, at best, defective under Windows in multimonitor conditions (remember you only have one AGP slot, so all of the additional cards were plugged into a shared 33 MHz PCI bus). Just the process of dumping raw images to the cards works roughly at 5 fps. In addition we needed to generate the intermediate frames for the transitions in real time, and an operation like weight-averaging two frames for a simple fade is very time consuming. This process was also added in the prefetching code.

The system is designed to be controlled from inside the CAVE, so the remote control has to be radio-based (i.e., non optical). These kind of controls are usually mice or small trackballs with two or three buttons, and are not very comfortable to use (try turning the trackball with the thumb while you press a button), so intuitive interactive operations were designed: step forward and backwards, and the possibility of adding a popup menu of basic functions (rewind, fast-forward) on the third button. This kind of interaction, though, proved to be more than enough for the desired type of presentations.

Before the presentation, the audience is given polarised glasses. During the presentation, they are prompted (by means of a static virtual actor) to put them on or take them off, depending on whether the images are stereoscopic or not.

Figure 4 gives a rough description of the dimensions of the system. Figure 5 shows a few pictures of the actual CLS that was built. For simplicity, it was decided not to have a floor or a ceiling, at least in this first prototype. The ceiling, though, has been covered with a black canvas, so as not to let any light out. Similarly, the room the CLS is in has been painted in matte black to absorb any light filtering in or bouncing off the screens.

Results

The simulation was asked for by CAF (Construcciones y Auxiliar de Ferrocarriles [40]), with Renfe [33], the most important train company in Spain, as the final client. More than twenty minutes of computer generated imagery made the cut for the final version of the simulation. As already stated, this imagery included both static images and animation, with and without stereoscopy. In addition to pure synthetic images, augmented virtuality techniques [32] were also used, for instance, to have the train come to a stop in a real train station, which was carefully photographed in advance for that purpose. The images were sent to the projectors either in SVGA format or S-Video format. SVGA was used for static imagery, with transitions and fades calculated in real time by one of the PCs. Those images were rendered at a resolution of 1024 × 768. Images were limited to that resolution by the projectors’ native panel. Animations were sent in S-Video, at a resolution of 720 × 576. This time, the limitation was imposed by the graphic cards used to decode six MPEG-2 channels simultaneously. Perfect synchronisation of those cards was required in order to preserve continuity in the images projected onto the different screens, and to maintain the stereoscopy. This was achieved by coding another program, that would use the software libraries of the own cards.

The simulation was controlled by one script in the case of dynamic presentations of static imagery. A wireless mouse was used to advance or retreat. An automatic version of the script that required no mouse interaction was also written but this was only used to drive the automatic mode presentations, not in the design phase. The animations were run by the graphic cards’ software, since little interaction was required.

After initial tests, it was decided to start the presentation with the S-Video animations, including the train coming to a stop in the real station and the surrounding stereoscopic walks inside the train. Then we would turn to SVGA, thus presenting higher-resolution images. Doing it the other way around would have meant a decline in quality, which initial tests proved to be unpleasant.

In order to inform the audience and help them with orientation issues (whether they are looking from the cabin or to the cabin, for instance), a virtual stewardess is introduced; this synthetic hostess guides the users throughout the presentation, explaining what parts are going to be seen, and prompting them to put on the stereoscopic glasses or take them off; images of this virtual stewardess were generated in different positions, while a brief text next to her fulfilled the task. An audio version of the information was ruled out after initial tests proved it more disturbing than written text. Nevertheless, the system does have 3D sound effects and background music, which can be toggled on and off. A small map of the train is also shown on one of the side screens when necessary.

Animations were rendered on a render farm made of six double-processor stations with 1 GB of RAM, running Windows 2000. Eight additional machines were used to generate static imagery whenever the user would log off.

Table 1 shows some of the most relevant statistics of this simulation. Figure 6 shows the simulation running on the CLS, as well as several of the images produced.

We would also like to mention the fact that the legal patent process for the system has already been initiated by the authors.

User feedback

Approximately 600 people have seen the presentation in the CLS, distributed in more than one hundred sessions. The feedback from them has always, without exception, been extremely positive and enthusiastic.

Everybody could see the stereoscopic images in 3D, which was a big concern in the beginning. As warned by the existing literature, stereoscopy is a subjective matter. To begin with, it has been calculated for an ideal observer placed on an ideal spot. It is safe to assure that none of the estimated 300-plus people exactly matched all the measures and distances involved in the calculation. The accommodation-convergence issue was also a source of worries, but again everybody was able to see the stereoscopy without much effort. The stereoscopic images are lengthy enough to provide the observers with plenty of time to adapt, in case they cannot see the stereoscopy right away.

People with a certain degree of knowledge of the technology involved did perceive the loss of quality in the MPEG-2 animations when compared to the S-VGA static imagery, but understood the causes and were willing to ignore it during the presentation. People with no knowledge of the technology considered the initial MPEG-2 animations as being high quality already, only to have their expectations surpassed even further when the following, higher-resolution S-VGA images were projected.

Nobody felt any motion sickness at all, which was another major point of concern for the CLS design team. The system has no floor projection, so during animations the three surrounding walls are “moving” while the floor remains static. That, plus the logical absence of inertia, were factors for potential motion sickness. The effects were minimised from the beginning by not panning the camera around, limiting the movement to straight trajectories inside the train and painting the floor black. Short animations and an appropriate walking speed did the rest of the job of keeping motion sickness away.

From the point of view of the train companies (CAF and Renfe), the presentation was also a complete success: Renfe came to the conclusion that this digital approach is a better alternative to the conventional full-size model, and will demand it as part of future contracts with CAF. On the other hand, Renfe and CAF have plans under way to move the CLS to Madrid and Valencia, respectively, for public exhibition, presenting it as a revolutionary and innovative approach to the train design process.

In the last few weeks, almost 300 computer engineering students from the University of Zaragoza have viewed the presentation in the CLS. Their assignment afterwards was to answer a questionnaire, providing the authors with some extensive user feedback and hopefully new ideas to improve and to expand the system. The answers were overwhelmingly positive, reassuring the authors the accomplishment of the intended goals in this project. Some of them were also asked to prepare their own individualised presentations using the PreCAVE software. Again, the feedback obtained was positive in terms of ease of use and versatility.

Conclusions

A train simulator entirely developed by the Grupo de Informática Gráfica Avanzada of the University of Zaragoza has been presented. The simulator, based on a low-cost CLS architecture, is fully functional, and has already been used in several simulations with CAF and Renfe staff with satisfactory results.

The possibility of not using a real model for the design process of a train has been proven. Many variations can be presented sharing a common design in a cheap, fast way. Images with different illuminations, floors, seats, doors, windows or colour schemes can be rendered to be viewed and compared full-size, even side to side if necessary. Elements can be hidden or shown in isolation, and either in a full-size or blown-up full screen for better study.

By adding people to the images, the real perception of the train can be visualised. An empty train interior tends to look dull, since usually the colour schemes used are meant that way. As the Renfe management puts it, “people are the colour of the train”. This fact was proved by showing empty images first, then adding different configurations of people sitting, staring out the window, walking down the corridors, etc.

Many changes in the design of the train were induced by the images produced. The seats, for instance, the design of which had been approved based on their orthographic views, were found not to look so good from a natural, passenger’s point of view, and so they were sent back to the drafting table. Also, a slightly darker hue was chosen when early rendering tests showed poor contrasts with the train walls and ceiling. Displays on the outside were made bigger for better reading, after the augmented virtuality test of the train coming to a stop in a real station showed poor readability. Monitors were raised a little bit higher, after visibility tests were conducted placing virtual people standing up next to them. Several seats were removed after animatics showed they took up too much space. The original colour chosen for the floor carpet was changed after illumination tests, where waste baskets were redesigned, and speakers made a bit smaller. These are just some of the changes that could be easily done in the digital realm, but would have cost a lot more to implement with a real model. Not only were they faster this way, but the flexibility of the system allowed CAF and Renfe to explore more creative paths than they usually would have, coming up with a far better product from an aesthetic and ergonomic point of view.

Finally, the feedback obtained from the users regarding the presentations inside the CLS has been enthusiastic and very positive.

Running the simulation with people inside the CLS allowed us to come up with two important conclusions as well. The first one is the fact that, even though there is only one ideal point of view from which perspective and stereoscopy have been calculated, any mismatches or discontinuities perceived by people not standing exactly on the ideal point are subconsciously assumed, not causing any discomfort while viewing the images. The second conclusion involves the tendency of people to look up front to the central screen. Unless the focal point of the image lies intentionally on one of the side screens, people use them just for peripheral vision, enough so they can feel the sense of immersion. This fact helps in the stereoscopic views, since they are calculated supposing that the person is looking straight down the central screen.

Future work

The most obvious future focus of work is to include real-time imagery in the system, with head-tracking devices that would receive the position of the head as input and would calculate the corresponding perspective and stereoscopy accordingly. This would necessarily impose a reduction in the quality of the images that could be generated, in keeping with the PC-based, low cost approach of the CLS. Instead of pre-rendered, high quality imagery, the images would have to settle for a more basic OpenGL-shaded look, with pre-lit, fine textures. Therefore, a hybrid approach that would mix between real time and high quality seems the most favourable combination.

A second focus of future work could be to add another level of interaction to the system, by capturing input from the user during animations and having the user react accordingly. This would, for instance, enable the user to choose between different precalculated animation paths at specific points, all done in real time and without any perceptible discontinuities in the animations.

The addition to the CLS of a floor with projected images is one of the issues that could be addressed in a future version. It would be necessary to achieve a greater sense of immersion, especially during animations. However, the current setup would become increasingly more complicated and expensive, verging on overkill for the intended simulation.

Another field open for future work is the substitution of the S-Video channel for another option that imposes less restrictions on the output resolution, as well as hopefully less compression. One option would be to change the PC with the MPEG-2 decoding cards for seven PCs under a master-slave architecture, and synchronise them so that each one sends one SVGA video. Another option would mean converting the animations to digital video and showing them in progressive DVD format.
